texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I recently came across a server that was throwing this error into its message log:
texts.text: I recently came across a server that was throwing this error into its message log:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: ntpd_initres[2619]: ntpd returns a permission denied error!
texts.text: ntpd_initres[2619]: ntpd returns a permission denied error!

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: It would only appear about every five minutes on the server, and restarting ntpd didn't correct the issue. I stopped ntpd entirely, but the error still appeared a few minutes later.
texts.text: It would only appear about every five minutes on the server, and restarting ntpd didn't correct the issue. I stopped ntpd entirely, but the error still appeared a few minutes later.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: After examining the running processes, I found that there was a lonely ntpd process that was running using a non-standard method. I killed that process, started the default instance of ntpd using the init scripts, and the issue went away.
texts.text: After examining the running processes, I found that there was a lonely ntpd process that was running using a non-standard method. I killed that process, started the default instance of ntpd using the init scripts, and the issue went away.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: It turns out that ntpd daemon that was started manually was unable to access some of the required paths and sockets that is necessary for ntpd to run properly. These configuration items are set up in the init scripts, but they're not included when ntpd is running manually.
texts.text: It turns out that ntpd daemon that was started manually was unable to access some of the required paths and sockets that is necessary for ntpd to run properly. These configuration items are set up in the init scripts, but they're not included when ntpd is running manually.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This was tested on Red Hat Enterprise Linux 4.
texts.text: This was tested on Red Hat Enterprise Linux 4.
